10.1016/j.mcat.2021.111550 The Author(s) Fig. 1 Representative TEM images of Pd (a) and Pd1Ag3 (b) catalysts. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 FTIR spectra of CO adsorbed on Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts. The spectra were obtained at 50 °C under 0.5 vol. % CO/He flow (30 mL/min). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 The performance of Pd/Al2O3 (a) and Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 (b) in liquid-phase hydrogenation of DPA; (c) dependence of selectivity toward stilbene formation on DPA conversion. P(H2) = 5 bar, m(Pd/Al2O3) =1.5 mg, m(Pd1Ag3/Al2O3)=10 mg. DPA – Diphenylacetylene, cis-/trans-St – cis-/trans-Stilbene, Bibenzyl – Diphenylethane. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene over Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts: a) dependence of the reaction rate on hydrogen pressure, b) selectivity dependence on conversion at different H2 pressure. T =25 °C, m(Pd/Al2O3) =1.5 mg, m(Pd1Ag3/Al2O3)=10 mg, V C6H14 = 6 mL. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene over Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts: a) Dependence of the reaction rate on the initial DPA concentration, b) Selectivity to stilbene as a function of DPA conversion for different initial DPA concentrations. Graphical abstract Catalytic performance of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 single-atom alloy (SAA) catalyst was studied in liquid-phase hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) and compared with the performance of the reference monometallic Pd/Al2O3. Formation of SAA structure in Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 was confirmed by FTIR CO technique. It was found that Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 single-atom alloy catalyst exhibits excellent selectivity in diphenylethene (stilbene) (ca. 98 %), which remains constant over a wide range of DPA conversions (0–95%), while over Pd/Al2O3 selectivity decreases steadily with the increase in DPA conversion. It is remarkable that the selectivity of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 depends neither on hydrogen pressure (5–15 bar), nor on DPA concentration (0.0262 – 0.159 mol/l). In contrast, over the reference Pd/Al2O3 selectivity tends to decrease with increasing P(H2) and decreasing DPA concentration. The proposed reaction network comprises hydrogenation of DPA in a parallel formation of cis and trans-stilbene with following hydrogenation to bibenzyl and direct formation of the latter from the initial DPA. The calculations clearly shows the capability of the kinetic model to describe the experimental dependencies for Pd1Ag3 single-atom catalyst in an excellent way with the degree of explanation equal to ca. 99 %. Keywords Diphenylacetylene Hydrogenation Single-atom catalysis Selectivity Kinetics Introduction The concept of single-atom catalysts (SACs) has attracted special attention during the last decade [1–10]. SACs are the heterogeneous catalytic systems with active sites consisting of only one active metal atom. This approach makes it possible to significantly improve the catalyst performance due to the high degree of homogeneity of the active sites [2]. One example of a single-atom catalyst namely Pt1/FeOx demonstrated high activity and excellent stability in CO oxidation compared to a commercial Au/Fe2O3 [11]. Another impressive example is the Pd1/graphene catalyst, which showed extremely high butadiene-to-butene selectivity in 1,3-butadiene hydrogenation of almost 100 % at 95 % butadiene conversion [12]. However, one of the serious drawbacks of SAC is the tendency of active metal atoms to agglomerate under reaction conditions at elevated temperature or upon regeneration [13], which limits the use of SACs in industrial processes. Alternatively, “single-atom” structure of active sites can be obtained on the surface of a bimetallic alloy. Sykes and Flytzani-Stephanopoulos defined this new class of heterogeneous alloyed catalysts as “single‐atom alloys” or SAA. In these catalysts the atoms of the active metal are completely isolated from each other by atoms of another metal [14,15]. In other words SAAs are the catalytic systems with the single atoms of an active metal alloyed into the surface of a less reactive host metal [16–18]. It is important to note that thermodynamic stability of SAA structure allows their high-temperature regeneration, which makes them promising for industrial applications. Efficiency of SAAs as an attractive alternative to traditional bimetallic catalysts for selective alkyne hydrogenation was demonstrated in several studies [15,19–22]. Interest in this process is due to the fact that catalytic hydrogenation of acetylenic compounds is of industrial relevance as an effective way for the purification of olefin streams used for polymerization. For unsupported PdCu SAA high activity and selectivity in hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene was first reported in [14]. The partial hydrogenation of phenylacetylene was investigated using Pd0.18Cu50/Al2O3 SAA catalyst [23]. Selectivity to styrene exceeding 94 % was observed within the whole conversion range, which was almost 10-fold higher as compared to the monometallic counterpart with the same metal loading. Later formation of SAA structures for Pd-Cu/Al2O3 catalysts was confirmed by Cao et al. using HAADF-STEM and H2-chemsorption [24]. Due to their SAA structure Pd-Cu catalysts exhibit excellent (>73 %) selectivity to ethylene at acetylene conversion over 99 %. High selectivity of SAA catalysts in acetylene hydrogenation was also revealed by Pei et al. for PdCu, PdAu and PdAg catalysts [19–22]. By diluting Pd with a second metal, the authors found that an excess of the latter is a prerequisite for the successful preparation of SAAC. Excellent selectivity to ethylene was explained by a higher electron density on single Pd atoms within the alloy decreasing the strength of the π-bonded ethylene adsorption over such electron-rich atoms [20]. This explanation was supported by a microcalorimetric study of ethylene adsorption on SAA Pd-Ag catalyst, which demonstrated a lower ethylene adsorption enthalpy compared to monometallic Pd analogue [21,22]. As can be seen from the studies cited above, the performance of SAA catalysts in the gas-phase selective hydrogenation of acetylene has been intensively investigated. For example catalysts based on the Pd-Ag composition are efficient in gas-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene [25–29]. However, their catalytic characteristics in the liquid-phase hydrogenation of substituted alkyne compounds remains insufficiently studied, despite the fact that this is a key process for important transformations of internal alkynes into cis- and trans-alkene moieties serving as building blocks in pharmaceutical and fine chemical industries. Therefore, in this study the investigation was focused on the properties of PdAg single-atom alloy catalyst in this process. The main idea of this investigation was to study the kinetics of selective alkyne hydrogenation on monometallic Pd and PdAg SAA catalysts and to develop kinetic models, adequately describing experimental data. Selective liquid-phase hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) previously studied in detail [30–32], was used as a model reaction. A significant advantage of this reaction is a possibility to carry it out at room temperature, therefore minimizing the effect of the adsorbate induced surface segregation on the structure of surface active sites. Otherwise an increase in the reaction temperature enhances mobility of Pd atoms, which, in turn, facilitates the formation of multiatomic Pdn sites (n ≥ 2) upon surface segregation of Pd. The latter, induced by adsorption of CO or alkyne, decreases the desirable selectivity to the alkene [33,34]. For preparation of PdAg SAA catalyst we use the methodology developed in our recent study of the formation of the structure of Pd1 sites isolated by Ag atoms on the surface of PdAg bimetallic nanoparticles [35]. It was found that a stable surface structure of single-atom Pd1 sites can be attained at Ag/Pd ratio of 2/1 or above. These data are in agreement with the theoretical calculations, demonstrating that a significant excess of Ag is a prerequisite for the formation of Pd1 isolated sites [36]. In order to ensure formation of SAA structure in this study the Ag/Pd ratio was increased to ca. 3/1. Experimental Catalyst preparation First, alumina powder (98.9 %, PURALOX 200/55, Sasol, Germany; SBET = 56 m2/g) was calcined in dry air flow at 500 °C for 4 h and then was impregnated by the incipient-wetness method with solutions of Pd(NO3)2 (99.9 %, Sigma-Aldrich) and Ag(NO3)2 (≥ 99.0 %, Sigma-Aldrich). After impregnation sample was dried at room temperature overnight and calcined in dry air flow (300 mL/min) at 550 °C for 4 h. To obtain the Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 catalyst the parent material was reduced in 5%H2/Ar flow at 550 °C for 3 h, cooled down in 5 % H2/Ar to 200 °C, and then in N2 (99.999 %) flow to room temperature. According to ICP-AES analysis, the metal content was 2.0 wt% Pd and 5.97 wt %Ag (designated as Pd1Ag3). The reference 0.5 wt. % Pd/Al2O3 catalyst was obtained using the same preparation procedure (designated as Pd). To obtain similar metal particle sizes for both Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 and Pd/Al2O3 catalysts the latter one was reduced at 700 °C for 3 h. Catalyst characterization To analyze the particle size distribution and to determine the average particle size transmission electron microscopy (TEM) was performed. The TEM images were collected with a Hitachi HT 7700 electron microscope (Japan) in the bright-field regime at an accelerating voltage of 100 kV. The catalysts were powdered and ultrasonically dispersed from a suspension in isopropanol to copper gauze with a diameter of 3 mm covered with a carbon film. The size distribution was estimated by measuring 150–200 particles located in different parts of the samples. The average nanoparticle size was calculated as follows: d av = Σnidi/n, where d av is the average diameter of nanoparticles, nm; ni is the number of nanoparticles with a diameter di; n is the total number of nanoparticles. The methodology of analytical measurements was described elsewhere [37]. The diffuse reflectance IR spectra of adsorbed CO (DRIFTS−CO) were measured using a Tensor 27 IR spectrometer (Bruker, Germany) equipped with a Harrick Diffuse Reflectance Kit for in situ measurements (Harrick Scientific Products, UK) under flow conditions. The reduced catalyst (20 mg) was placed in a thermostatically controlled cell with CaF2 windows and heated to 500 °C for 1 h in Ar flow (30 mL/min). Thereafter, it was reduced at 550 °C for 1 h in a 5 % H2/Ar (30 mL/min) flow and cooled first in 5% H2/Ar (30 mL/min) flow to 300 °C and then in Ar (30 mL/min) flow to 50 °C. The background spectrum was recorded under Ar flow (30 mL/min) at 50 °C. The spectra of adsorbed CO were collected at 50 °C in a 0.5 vol. % CO/He flow for 10 min (30 mL/min; 250 scans; resolution, 4 cm–1). Fig. 2 shows FTIR−CO spectra obtained after 10 min of CO exposure. Catalytic tests Commercially available diphenylacetylene (98 %, Sigma-Aldrich) was used as a substrate, being additionally purified by distillation under Ar atmosphere. The solvent was n-hexane (98 %, Merck, Germany). The liquid-phase hydrogenation was performed as described in details elsewhere [31]. Typical catalytic tests were carried out at 25 °C, initial hydrogen pressure of 5 bar, and 1000 rpm stirring. External mass-transfer limitations were avoided on the basis of the experiments with different stirring rates [38]. It was shown that at stirring rates exceeding 600 rpm identical activity and selectivity were obtained. To minimize the internal mass-transfer limitations the catalyst was finely grinded to obtain a powder with a particle size below 10 μm as suggested in [39]. Calculations of the Weisz-Prater criterion [40] for the highest reaction rate considering hydrogen concentration in the solvent and effective diffusion coefficient of hydrogen, a porosity to tortuosity ratio of 0.1, gave the values of the Weisz-Prater criterion below 0.02, pointing out that the internal mass transfer limitations can be ruled out. Experiments with different catalyst amounts demonstrated that the gas-liquid mass transfer was not the limiting factor. The liquid probes were taken at regular intervals and analyzed by gas chromatography (GC) using a Crystal 5000 instrument (Chromatek, Russia) equipped with a flame-ionization detector and an HP5-MS column (5% phenyldimethylsiloxane; 30 m, 0.25 mm I.D., 0.25 μm film thickness). Results and discussion Transmission electron microscopy Transmission electron microscopy was used to estimate the morphology and particle size distribution of supported Pd and PdAg nanoparticles (Fig. 1 ). All catalysts were reduced in a 5 % H2/Ar flow at 550 °C for 1 h immediately before TEM measurements. Both Pd/Al2O3 and Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 catalysts contain almost spherical particles evenly distributed on the alumina surface. The size distribution is unimodal with d av about 5.4 and 6.4 nm for Pd/Al2O3 and Pd1Ag3/Al2O3, respectively. In accordance with the previously obtained XRD data [35] the bimetallic PdAg catalyst exhibited by Pd1Ag3 particles of a substituted solid solution with the core-shell structure, where the shell is significantly enriched with Ag owing to its surface segregation. IR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO The surface structure of the prepared catalysts was studied by FTIR spectroscopy of adsorbed CO (Fig. 2 ). The spectrum of CO adsorbed on Pd/Al2O3 monometallic Pd contains intense absorption bands with a maximum at 1982 cm−1 and a shoulder at 1944 cm−1 characteristic of the stretching vibrations of bridge-bonded CO and triple bridge-bonded CO at a hollow site, respectively [41,42]. According to [43,44], the maximum at 1982 cm-1 can be a superposition of the bridge-bonded CO on edges and steps and a certain fraction of adsorbed CO on Pd(100) facets. The asymmetric peak at 1944 cm-1 can be ascribed to bridge-bonded CO, adsorbed mainly on Pd(111) faces. The band centered at 2086 cm-1 belongs to linear adsorbed CO on Pd(100) facets and edges [43]. For Pd1Ag3 catalyst the bands characteristic of the multicoordinated CO adsorption almost completely disappeared (a trace peak at 1958 cm−1), and the band of linearly adsorbed CO with a maximum at 2044 cm−1 becomes dominant, indicating formation of single-atom Pd1 sites isolated from each other by Ag atoms, which is characteristic of SAA catalysts. Similar findings were reported in literature. Thus, the absence of bridged-bound CO on the surface of Ag0.975Pd0.025/SiO2 was considered as evidence of only Pd1 sites presence on the surface of PdAg catalyst [22]. McCue and Anderson studying PdCu/Al2O3 catalyst for selective acetylene hydrogenation also demonstrated that the absence of bridge-bonded and 3-fold hollow bonded CO (the region below 2020 cm−1) confirms the presence of the Pd1 sites without ensembles of neighboring Pd atoms [33]. The low-intensity adsorption band at 1958 cm−1 can be ascribed to bridge-bonded CO adsorbed on Pd-Pd neighboring sites (Pd-Pd dimers) on the surface of Pd-Ag nanoparticles, which is consistent with the frequencies of bridge-bonded CO species reported in [43,44]. The signal is symmetrical and does not contain a tail at lower wavenumbers typical for 3-fold-hollow bound CO, which is inevitably present on the surface of monometallic Pd nanoparticles (see the Pd spectrum in Fig. 2). Previously, formation of Pd-Pd dimers on the surface of PdCu SAA catalyst was reported in [33] and confirmed in our previous study of PdAg/Al2O3 catalysts [35]. It is informative to estimate a possible contribution of Pd-Pd dimers to hydrogenation on the basis of FTIR−CO data. Considering that the FTIR−CO spectra were obtained at 50 °C and do not correspond to the saturated CO coverage, this assessment should be done with caution. However, even a semi-quantitative estimate can be informative. Thus the integral intensity ratio of the linear CO band at 2044 cm−1 (Ilinear) and bridge-bonded CO at 1958 cm−1 (Ibridge) allows calculation of the intensity ratio Ibridge/(Ilinear + Ibridge) = 0.03. To evaluate the fraction of Pd-Pd dimers, it is also necessary to take into account the absorption coefficients of linear and bridging CO. The absorption coefficient of linearly adsorbed CO is approximately 20–25 times lower than the absorption coefficient of bridged CO [33,45]. Thus, taking into account a low intensity of the absorption band at 1958 cm−1, as well as a significant difference in the adsorption coefficients of bridging and linear adsorbed CO, it can be concluded that the fraction of Pd-Pd dimeric centers is extremely small. Catalytic performance of Pd/Al2O3 and Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 catalysts in DPA hydrogenation Fig. 3 shows the typical concentration profiles of DPA hydrogenation on Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts. Stilbene and bibenzyl are the only products detected under experimental conditions. The volcano-type trend observed for cis- and trans-stilbene implies the consecutive mechanism of the reaction comprising hydrogenation of DPA to stilbene and stilbene to bibenzyl. However, the catalytic performance of the catalysts is significantly different. For the Pd catalyst bibenzyl appears as the reaction products even at low DPA conversions exceeding 12 % after complete DPA hydrogenation (Fig. 3a). On the other hand, for Pd1Ag3 SAA catalyst the concentration of bibenzyl did not exceed 2% at 100 % DPA conversion (Fig. 3b). Calculation of the hydrogenation rates based on chromatographic analysis data shows that the rate of bibenzyl formation is 50 times lower than the rate of DPA hydrogenation over Pd1Ag3, while for the reference Pd sample this difference is significantly lower (ca. 14). As a result, a comparison of the cis-stilbene concentration profiles for Pd and Pd1Ag3 indicates that the maximum yield of stilbene is ca. 81%–94%, respectively. It is informative to analyze dependencies of the selectivity in stilbene formation on the DPA conversion for the reference Pd metallic and Pd1Ag3 single-atom catalysts (Fig. 3c). It is obvious that shapes for selectivity vs. conversion profiles were different for these catalysts. For supported Pd catalyst at 10 % DPA conversion stilbene selectivity does not exceed 95 % and tends to decrease steadily with an increase of DPA conversion. In contrast, for the Pd1Ag3 SAA catalyst high selectivity to the stilbene (around 98 %) is maintained up to 100 % DPA conversion. These data indicate that in terms of the overall reaction pathway for the PdAg catalyst the contribution of the direct hydrogenation of the triple bond to the corresponding alkane proceeding simultaneously with the semi- hydrogenation is negligible. Presumably this can be attributed to differences in the relative adsorption strength of diphenylacetylene and stilbene on Pd monometallic and Pd1Ag3 single-atom catalysts. Apparently stronger stilbene adsorption on monometallic Pd catalyst enhances bibenzyl formation due to its higher coverage and higher energy of stilbene desorption compared to the activation energy of olefin-to-alkane hydrogenation [46]. According to our previous results and the characterization data of this work the selectivity improvement can be assigned to formation of the SAA structure due to isolation of Pd1 from each other by Ag atoms on the surface of PdAg nanoparticles [35]. As it was shown by Pei et al. [22] and Smith and co-authors [47,48] for hydrogenation of acetylene to ethylene presence of Pd1 sites leads to a decrease of the olefin adsorption energy promoting thereby desorption of the latter. In this way olefin desorption on the catalyst surface becomes preferential compared to its further hydrogenation to the corresponding alkane. Effect of hydrogen pressure The hydrogen pressure effect was studied for both Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts and the results are displayed in Fig. 4 . For both catalysts with the increase in hydrogen pressure from 5 to 15 bar the initial hydrogenation rate increased two-fold: from 48.4 to 96.4 mmol H2 gcat −1 min−1 for the former and from 5.0 to 10.2 mmol H2 gcat −1 min−1 for the latter catalyst (Table S1). As can be seen from Fig. 4 a depicting dependence of the reaction rate on hydrogen pressure in logarithmic coordinates, the reaction order towards hydrogen is essentially the same for both catalysts, being 0.68 for Pd and 0.64 for Pd1Ag3, respectively. Similar values were reported in the literature. For example, the reaction order of 0.6 with respect to hydrogen was reported for 2-hexyne hydrogenation over Pd/W films [49]. Other liquid-phase hydrogenation reactions displayed similar orders in H2 [50]. It is noteworthy that for both monometallic Pd and SAA Pd1Ag3 the reaction orders in hydrogen are essentially identical. Interestingly, a lack of the reaction order in H2 dependence on the catalyst composition was previously reported by Pei et al. for AgPd/SiO2 and monometallic Pd/SiO2 catalysts [22]. The results can be rationalized by considering noncompetitive hydrogen adsorption which happens exclusively on Pd sites not being influenced by the presence of silver. This suggestion is in line with the results of DFT calculations indicating that H2 activation over AgPd bimetallic catalysts occurred on Pd sites, rather than Ag sites [25]. It is informative to analyze the effect of hydrogen pressure on the stilbene selectivity (Fig. 4b). For the monometallic Pd catalyst a gradual decline in selectivity was observed as H2 pressure increases from 5 to 10, and then to 15 bar. Thus at DPA conversion of ca. 80 % selectivity to stilbene is ca. 93 % at PH2 = 5 bar, and ca. 91 % at PH2 = 15 bar. Within the approach of a consecutive reaction mechanism with the same dependencies of both reaction steps on hydrogen pressure, selectivity is independent on hydrogen pressure and cannot be attributed just to a higher concentration of adsorbed hydrogen [51]. There are, however, several example in the literature reporting selectivity dependence in triple bond hydrogenation on hydrogen pressure, as for example in hydrogenation of heptyne-1 over Pt catalyst [52]. In the latter case when an excess of hydrogen in the reaction mixture leads to a decrease of selectivity with increasing alkyne conversion, a parallel-consecutive mechanism was proposed suggesting a strong involvement of a direct route of triple bond hydrogenation to a corresponding alkane. Lower selectivity at elevated pressures reported for hydrogenation of acetylene over Pd catalyst [53] was ascribed to formation of the Pd4H3 hydride phase. Such explanation of PdH hydride phase formation with an increase in the hydrogen partial pressure was also supported by Bond et al. [54]. For Pd1Ag3 catalyst the effect of hydrogen pressure on selectivity is negligible (Fig. 4b). In essence, this suggests that some mechanistic aspects of diphenylacetylene hydrogenation on Pd1 sites surrounded by inactive Ag atoms are not the same as for supported monometallic palladium, making selectivity less sensitive with respect to H2 partial pressure [22]. Effect of DPA concentration The effect of the substrate concentration on the hydrogenation rate was studied by varying the DPA concentration from 0.0262 to 0.159 mol/l (Fig. 5 ). It was found that the initial hydrogenation rate is almost independent on the substrate concentration. Thus a decrease of the DPA concentration diminished the hydrogenation rate for monometallic Pd catalyst only from 48.36 to 47.12 mmol H2 gcat −1 min−1 and for Pd1Ag3 from 5.01 to 3.74 mmol H2 gcat −1 min−1 (Table S2). The reaction order calculated from the logarithmic plot of the hydrogenation rate vs. DPA concentration (Fig. 5a) was found to be close to zero (more precisely 0.08 for both Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts). This is in agreement with the literature implying that the catalyst surface is saturated with a strongly bound alkyne. Similar values of the reaction orders were reported by Reyes and co-workers in liquid-phase hydrogenation of 1-phenyl-1-propyne, 1-phenyl-1-butyne and 1-phenyl-1-pentyne over Pd catalysts supported on a pillared clay and a commercial Ca-montmorillonite [55] and by Jung et al. in hydrogenation of 1-octyne over Pd deposited on carbon nanomaterials [56]. The dependence of the stilbene selectivity on the DPA conversion for the monometallic Pd catalyst demonstrates a gradual decrease in selectivity (Fig. 5b) with an increase in DPA conversion. It should be mentioned that higher DPA concentration favors selectivity in stilbene. Thus. at DPA conversion exceeding 90 % selectivity was changing from ca. 92 % for the initial DPA concentration of 0.159 mol/l to ca. 89 % for [DPA] = 0.0262 mol/l. Similar results were obtained previously for hydrogenation of phenylacetylene [57]. In particular it was shown that selectivity to styrene decreases from ca. 87 to ca. 70 % with decrease of the initial phenylacetylene concentration from 22 mM to 11 mM. A strong effect of the initial alkyne concentration on selectivity was demonstrated for hydrogenation of 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol [58] and ascribed to the strong concentration dependence of pore diffusion for the substrate and the intermediate influencing selectivity. SAA Pd1Ag3 catalyst demonstrated significantly different dependence of the stilbene selectivity on the DPA concentration. Unlike the reference monometallic Pd catalyst, selectivity of SAA Pd1Ag3 catalyst did not change upon variation of DPA concentration (Fig. 5b). The most plausible explanation of selectivity enhancement is based on a decrease of the relative adsorption strength of the intermediate alkene in comparison with the alkyne on isolated Pd1 sites. Thus, if an ensemble of palladium atoms Pdn (n>1) is needed for adsorption of alkene [58], introduction of silver and in this way a decrease in the ensemble size to Pd1 will eventually disfavor the olefin adsorption hindering its further hydrogenation. Effect of hydrogen pressure on the formation of alkane in the presence and absence of DPA It is informative to analyze the effect of H2 pressure on the rates of alkane formation in the presence and absence of the parent DPA (Fig. 6 ). In the former case the rate of the alkene hydrogenation is lower for Pd1Ag3 as compared to palladium counterpart. The reaction orders towards alkene are respectively 0.99 and 0.62 for Pd and Pd1Ag3 (Fig. 6a). After complete DPA hydrogenation the reaction orders toward the alkene decreased significantly to 0.5 and 0.39 for the monometallic Pd and bimetallic single-atom Pd1Ag3 catalyst. Reaction network The reaction network in hydrogenation of DPA was discussed in our previous publication (Fig. 7 ). Similar to the previous studies [31] the reaction network comprises hydrogenation of DPA in a parallel fashion to cis- and trans-stilbene, hydrogenation of olefins to bibenzyl and direct formation of the latter from the alkyne. Such direct formation of the alkane was discussed previously in the connection of gas-phase hydrogenation of acetylene to ethane [59] and liquid-phase hydrogenation of 3-methyl-1-pentyn-3-ol [60]. The aim of kinetic analysis in [31] was limited to an investigation of the structure sensitivity aspects of DPA hydrogenation when the experiments were performed at the same hydrogen pressure. The current work clearly demonstrates that in the case of monometallic Pd catalyst selectivity to the intermediate olefins depends on hydrogen pressure, namely that higher hydrogen pressure results in lower selectivity. At the same time on Pd1Ag3 “single-atom alloy” catalyst selectivity behavior vs DPA conversion was independent on hydrogen pressure (Fig. 4) requiring adequate kinetic explanations. Moreover, there was a substantial difference in selectivity for Pd and Pd1Ag3 catalysts at different initial concentrations of DPA. In the former case higher initial concentration afforded higher selectivity, which was not the case for the “single-atom” Pd-Ag catalyst, where selectivity ceased to depend on the initial content of the substrate. Experimental data reported recently for the gas phase acetylene hydrogenation [59] are in line with the experimental observations in the current work on hydrogen pressure dependence for the first and the second steps of hydrogenation (i.e. hydrogenation of the triple and double bonds, respectively) in the case of single-atom palladium. Besides independence on the hydrogen pressure the reaction orders in the reactants (acetylene and ethylene) are close to each other implying independence of selectivity on the initial partial pressure of acetylene. The subsequent kinetic modelling in [59] was based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of kinetic model considering adsorption of the alkyne and the olefin along with dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on the same type of sites. The zero order towards DPA implying almost complete coverage of the surface with the alkyne and the reaction order in hydrogen clearly exceeding at the same time 0.5 rather call for an alternative explanation, still within the framework of the Langmuir-Hinshelwood kinetics. Namely noncompetitive adsorption of hydrogen and organic compounds and involvement of hydrogen either by molecular addition or as a pair of atoms in a concerted way should be considered. It clearly follows from Eq. (8) that selectivity to the olefin is independent on the hydrogen pressure and the initial concentration of the alkyne, displaying, however, a decrease of selectivity as a function of conversion. Apparently the steepness of selectivity decrease upon conversion elevation depends on the ratio k 3 K C / ( k 1 + k 2 + k 5 ) K A . Similar cases are treated in textbooks on catalytic kinetics [61]. Thus, the model comprising 5 rate constants (1–5) and 4 adsorption constants (alkyne, cis- and trans-stilbene and dihydrogen) was used to predict concentration dependences of the reactant and 3 products in hydrogenation over a single-atom catalyst. The degree of explanation R2 , defined as the ratio of the squared difference in the experimental and the estimated values of concentrations of all components, and the square of the differences between the experimental and the mean of the estimated concentrations, reflects the goodness of the fit [61]. The Levenberg − Marquardt algorithm implemented in the optimization software ModEst software was used [62]. The parameter estimation was done for the whole data sets at all pressures and initial concentrations simultaneously by numerically solving the differential Eq. (7). The results are presented in Table 1 and Fig. 8 clearly illustrates capability of the model to describe the experimental concentration dependencies in an excellent way with the degree of explanation equal to 98.6 %. The low values of parameters errors (Table 1) are in line with the Markov Chain Monte-Carlo analysis (Figs. S1 and S2) confirming that the parameters are well identified and there are no apparent correlations between the parameters. As expected the value for the adsorption constant of DPA is much higher than the corresponding value for cis-stilbene. The model is capable to capture a large difference between the rates of alkyne and alkenes hydrogenation, as well as dependence on hydrogen pressure and the initial substrate concentration. Contrary to hydrogenation over a SAA catalyst, kinetic regularities observed over a monometallic catalyst were quite different, implying that the Langmuir-Hinshelwood type of mechanism applicable for the SAA catalyst cannot be used modelling of the data with a monometallic counterpart. In particular selectivity was seen to be dependent on hydrogen pressure and the initial concentration of the reactant. Subsequently it can be hypothesized, at least from the mathematical viewpoint, that the terms containing hydrogen pressure dependence should be different for hydrogenation of the triple and double bonds. Moreover, the denominators in the rate equation (i.e. of the type 2–6) for hydrogenation of the alkyne and olefins cannot have the same form. Conceptually a clear difference in kinetic behavior between a single-atom Pd1Ag3 and the monometallic Pd catalyst can be explained by the existence of the Eley-Rideal mechanism in the former case for hydrogenation of the alkyne contrary to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism which is operative for olefins hydrogenation on the monometallic catalyst. To comply with a much higher reaction order towards hydrogen in hydrogenation of DPA compared to stilbene, dissociative adsorption of hydrogen on palladium monometallic catalyst was proposed in line with experimental observations and theoretical studies [63,64]. The kinetic interpretation of such mechanism is given below: (9) r P d ( I ) = k 1 K A C A P H 2 1 + K A C A + K C C C + K T C T + K H P H 2 (10) r P d ( I I ) = k 2 K A C A P H 2 1 + K A C A + K C C C + K T C T + K H P H 2 (11) r P d ( I I I ) = k 3 K C C C K H P H 2 ( 1 + K A C A + K C C C + K T C T + K H P H 2 ) 2 (12) r P d ( I V ) = k 4 K T C T K H P H 2 ( 1 + K A C A + K C C C + K T C T + K H P H 2 ) 2 (13) r P d ( I V ) = k 5 K A C A P H 2 1 + K A C A + K C C C + K T C T + K H P H 2 Eqs. (9)–(13) imply that when DPA is present in the reaction mixture it is strongly adsorbed occupying the surface sites. When DPA is fully consumed by hydrogenation to the olefin, sites on the surface are becoming available for dissociative adsorption of hydrogen, which then competes for these sites with organic compounds. The results of kinetic modelling performed using the same methodology as for the single-atom catalyst show a good correspondence to the experimental data (Fig. 9 ). Note that an attempt to model the data for the monometallic Pd catalyst using eq. (2–7) was unsuccessful as expected, taking into account that that set of equations cannot explain selectivity dependence on hydrogen pressure and the initial concentration of DPA. Despite a high degree of explanation the statistical analysis of the values of kinetic parameters indicate poor identifiability of some of them (Table 2 ). Conclusions Kinetics of liquid-phase diphenylacetylene hydrogenation over Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 single-atom alloy (SAA) catalyst was studied using also monometallic Pd/Al2O3 as a reference. Formation of surface structure of Pd1 sites isolated from each other by Ag atoms in Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 was confirmed using FTIR CO technique by the complete disappearance of the signal characteristic of bridged or triple bridged CO species requiring multiatomic Pdn surface sites (n ≥ 2). Selectivity of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 SAA catalyst in diphenylethene (stilbene) was found to be extremely high (c.a. 98 %) remaining constant within a broad range of DPA conversions (0–95%). Unlike Pd1Ag3/Al2O3, selectivity of Pd/Al2O3 is lower and tends to decrease steadily with the increasing DPA conversion from ca. 95 to 87–88 %. Presumably, high stilbene selectivity of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 SAA catalyst stems from lower adsorption strength of the intermediate stilbene on single-atom Pd1 sites, disfavoring the olefin adsorption thereby hindering its further hydrogenation to bibenzyl. For both catalysts the effect of hydrogen pressure (5–15 bar) and DPA concentration (0.0262-0.159 mol/l) on the course of the hydrogenation reaction was also investigated. The reaction orders with respect to hydrogen were found to be essentially identical for the reference monometallic Pd and Pd1Ag3 SAA catalyst: 0.68 for Pd and 0.64 for Pd1Ag3, respectively. The reaction orders in DPA concentration are close to zero for both catalysts (c.a. 0.08) indicating saturation of the catalyst surface with strongly bound substrate molecules. Despite similar reaction orders, influence of P(H2) and DPA concentration on the stilbene selectivity is different for the catalysts under study. For monometallic Pd, a gradual decline in selectivity was observed with increasing hydrogen pressure and decreasing DPA concentration. In contrast to monometallic Pd, selectivity of Pd1Ag3 SAA catalyst essentially does not depend on P(H2) on selectivity or DPA concentration and the remains constant (c.a. 98 %). The specific kinetic characteristics of Pd1Ag3 SAA catalyst was captured by the kinetic model based on the reaction network comprising hydrogenation of DPA in a parallel fashion to cis- and trans-stilbene, hydrogenation of olefins to bibenzyl and direct formation of the latter from the alkyne. The proposed kinetic model was able to successfully describe the experimental dependencies for Pd1Ag3 single-atom catalyst in an excellent way with the degree of explanation equal to ca. 99 %. While there are many examples of bimetallic catalysts exhibiting high selectivity for partial hydrogenation of triple bonds with the general explanation that the apparent rate constants for hydrogenation of triple and double bonds change in the bimetallic versus monometallic samples, the current work goes beyond such explanations. In the case of a single-atom Pd1Ag3 catalyst the same type of noncompetitive Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism is operative for hydrogenation of the triple and double bonds, while for monometallic Pd catalyst the Eley-Rideal mechanism was proposed for the triple bond contrary to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism operative for olefins. coredata.dc:description: Catalytic performance of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 single-atom alloy (SAA) catalyst was studied in liquid-phase hydrogenation of diphenylacetylene (DPA) and compared with the performance of the reference monometallic Pd/Al2O3. Formation of SAA structure in Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 was confirmed by FTIR CO technique. It was found that Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 single-atom alloy catalyst exhibits excellent selectivity in diphenylethene (stilbene) (ca. 98 %), which remains constant over a wide range of DPA conversions (0–95%), while over Pd/Al2O3 selectivity decreases steadily with the increase in DPA conversion. It is remarkable that the selectivity of Pd1Ag3/Al2O3 depends neither on hydrogen pressure (5–15 bar), nor on DPA concentration (0.0262 – 0.159 mol/l). In contrast, over the reference Pd/Al2O3 selectivity tends to decrease with increasing P(H2) and decreasing DPA concentration. The proposed reaction network comprises hydrogenation of DPA in a parallel formation of cis and trans-stilbene with following hydrogenation to bibenzyl and direct formation of the latter from the initial DPA. The calculations clearly shows the capability of the kinetic model to describe the experimental dependencies for Pd1Ag3 single-atom catalyst in an excellent way with the degree of explanation equal to ca. 99 %.

coredata.dc:title: Kinetics of liquid-phase diphenylacetylene hydrogenation on “single-atom alloy” Pd-Ag catalyst: Experimental study and kinetic analysis
